Planets.name: Mercury
Planets.facts: Mercury, the smallest and closest planet to the Sun in our solar system, is a fascinating celestial body with distinctive characteristics.

Planets.name: Venus
Planets.facts: Venus, the second planet from the Sun, is distinguished by its scorching temperatures and thick atmosphere primarily composed of carbon dioxide. Its clouds contain sulfuric acid, adding to its hostile environment.

Planets.name: Earth
Planets.description: The only known planet with life.
Planets.facts: Earth, the third planet, is unique as the only known celestial body supporting life. With a diverse ecosystem, moderate temperatures, and a protective atmosphere, Earth is a haven for a vast array of living organisms.

Planets.name: Mars
Planets.description: Home to the tallest volcano, tallets mountain and the deepest canyon.
Planets.facts: Mars, the fourth planet from the Sun, is renowned for its distinctive reddish hue, earning it the moniker Red Planet.

Planets.name: Jupiter
Planets.description: Largest planet, known for its Great Red Spot.
Planets.facts: Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system, showcases a mesmerizing display of colorful bands and features the iconic Great Red Spot—a massive storm that has persisted for centuries.

Planets.name: Saturn
Planets.description: Known for its stunning ring system.
Planets.facts: Saturn, known for its stunning ring system, is a gas giant with icy rings that captivate observers. Its unique features make it a standout in our planetary lineup.

Planets.name: Uranus
Planets.description: Rotates on its side, with a unique tilted axis.
Planets.facts: Uranus , the ice giants, present distinct rotational axes and icy compositions in their atmospheres, contributing to their intriguing characteristics.

Planets.name: Neptune
Planets.description: Known for its deep blue color and strong winds.

Planets.name: Pluto
Planets.description: Dwarf planet in the outer reaches of the solar system.
Planets.facts: Pluto, once considered the ninth planet, is a dwarf planet located in the Kuiper Belt and is known for its complex system of moons, including Charon, Nix, and Hydra.

Planets.name: Eris
Planets.description: Dwarf planet in the scattered disc, known for its discovery leading to the reclassification of Pluto.
Planets.facts: Eris, a dwarf planet discovered in 2005, is about the same size as Pluto and played a key role in the reclassification of Pluto and the definition of what constitutes a planet in our solar system.

Planets.name: Haumea
Planets.description: Dwarf planet with an elongated shape, located in the Kuiper belt.
Planets.facts: Haumea is a dwarf planet with a unique elongated shape, believed to result from its rapid rotation. It has two moons, Hiʻiaka and Namaka, and is named after the Hawaiian goddess of childbirth and fertility.

Planets.name: Gliese 876 b
Planets.description: A blue gas giant, as big as Jupiter
Planets.facts: Gliese 86bm is a binary star system located in the constellation Hydra, showcasing the diverse nature of celestial bodies in our galaxy.

Planets.name: Ceres
Planets.description: Dwarf planet and the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
Planets.facts: Ceres, the largest object in the asteroid belt, offers insights into the early solar system and is considered a dwarf planet.

Planets.name: Kepler-22b
Planets.description: Exoplanet located in the habitable zone of the Kepler-22 system.
Planets.facts: Kepler-22b is an exoplanet orbiting a sun-like star, adding to the growing list of known planets beyond our solar system.

Planets.name: Trappist-1e
Planets.description: Exoplanet in the habitable zone of the Trappist-1 system.
Planets.facts: Trappist-1e is an Earth-sized exoplanet within the habitable zone of the Trappist-1 system, making it a target for potential exploration in the search for extraterrestrial life.
